Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officers erred in concluding applicants would not leave Canada by the end of their authorized stay
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.20(1)(b), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR) s.200(1)(b)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Assessment based on ties to home country, employment prospects, credibility of documents; some key evidence overlooked (e.g., Rico Baylon's employment certificate)
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review granted for Rico Baylon and Juan Dastas; dismissed for John Carreon, Glen Fuentes, and Romualdo C. Baylon
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of visa refusal decisions
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Decisions found unreasonable for two applicants, reasonable for three others
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Temporary foreign worker applicants from the Philippines
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Visa Officers assessed intent to return based on economic and familial ties
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Perceived lack of intent to return to home countries after temporary work permits expired
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Ties to home country, employment status, financial stability, family circumstances
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review process in Federal Court
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Some applicants' submitted documents were deemed credible; others lacked sufficient or credible evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Employment certificates, proof of residence, family ties, financial records
Crimes.Application_Basis: Intent to leave Canada at the end of authorized stay
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Employment letters, family situation, economic conditions in home country
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturning of visa refusal and remittal for reconsideration
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Applicants must demonstrate they will leave Canada by the end of their authorized stay
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible employment documentation for some applicants
Crimes.Outcome: Two cases remitted for reconsideration; three dismissed
Crimes.Decisional_Body: Visa Officers at Canadian visa offices
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Unlawful denial of entry despite lawful eligibility claims
Crimes.Cause_Description: Visa applications refused due to perceived lack of intent to return to home countries
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Inconsistent consideration of key evidence across cases
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Selective disregard of favorable evidence in certain cases
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Compliance with temporary stay conditions questioned
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: No finding of misrepresentation; issue centered on credibility and future intent
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Mixed quality and sufficiency of supporting documentation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Weak economic ties and insufficient proof of reintegration into home country
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider material evidence in two cases

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officers erred in concluding applicants would not leave Canada after their authorized stay
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 20(1)(b); Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 200(1)(b)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted in two cases, denied in three
Crimes.Procedural_Context: Judicial review of administrative immigration decisions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' credibility assessed based on consistency and plausibility of claims
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment records, family ties, financial status, travel history
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Doubt about genuine intent to return to home country after work permit expiration
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Strength of ties to home country (economic, familial, social)
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider material evidence (e.g., family situation)
Crimes.Review_Outcome: Two refusals set aside and remitted; three upheld
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Family circumstances and valid employment certification in specific cases
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Home country employment, family obligations, financial assets
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Two remanded for re-evaluation, three refusals upheld
Crimes.Decision_Review_Issue: Unreasonable application of legal test for intent to depart
Crimes.Governing_Rule_or_Provision: Applicants must prove they will leave Canada upon expiry of authorized stay
Crimes.Cause_of_Refusal: Perceived weak economic and familial ties to Philippines
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient documentation of employment; inconsistent credibility findings
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness: Alleged failure to fairly assess all relevant factors
Crimes.Credibility_Issues: Questions about authenticity and reliability of employment documents
Crimes.Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Challenge based on unreasonableness of decision-making process
Crimes.Relevant_Law: IRPA and IRPR provisions on temporary resident entry
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of visa officer decisions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Failure to satisfy requirement of intent to leave Canada after temporary stay
